about.title: About the Temple
about.subtitle: A Sacred Shaiva Kshetram of Great Antiquity
about.intro: Sri Agastheeswara Swamy Temple, Thondavada, is one of the most ancient and spiritually significant Shaiva temples in Andhra Pradesh. The temple is situated on the northern bank of the sacred Swarnamukhi River, at the foothills of the Tirumala Hills, the divine abode of Lord Sri Venkateswara.
about.deityDesc1: The presiding deity is Lord Shiva, worshipped as Sri Agastheeswara Swamy. The Shiva Lingam was discovered by Sage Agastya while bathing in the Swarnamukhi River. He consecrated it on the riverbank and installed it as Sri Agastheeswara Swamy.
about.deityDesc2: Goddess Parvati Devi is revered as Sri Anandavalli Ammavaru and is worshipped in a separate shrine within the temple complex. She is revered as the embodiment of compassion and bliss, and devotees seek her blessings for marital harmony, prosperity, and family well-being.
about.connectionDesc1: The temple holds a unique spiritual association with Lord Sri Venkateswara. After His divine marriage with Sri Padmavathi Devi at Narayanavanam, Lord Venkateswara stayed at Sage Agastya's ashram on the banks of the Swarnamukhi River.
about.connectionDesc2: During this period, He performed nitya poojas to Lord Shiva at this shrine. As per Sage Agastya's advice, the Lord remained here for six months before proceeding to Tirumala, later blessing this sacred place with His divine footprints.
about.shrinesOutside: Outside the compound are temples of Sri Bhadrachala Rama, Sri Krishna, and Sri Anjaneya.
about.mandapamDesc: There is a river-side stone mandapam located in the middle of the Swarnamukhi River. Within this mandapam, the sacred footprint of Lord Venkateswara is enshrined. The principal deities, Sri Harihara (Siva-Kesava) and Lord Ayyappa, are also installed inside the mandapam along with the divine footprint of Lord Venkateswara.

history.title: History & Legends
history.subtitle: Ancient Tales of Devotion and Divinity
history.legendDesc1: This sacred site was once the hermitage (ashrama) of the great Sage Agastya Maharshi, one of the revered Saptarishis. During his southward journey undertaken at the command of Lord Shiva to restore cosmic balance, Sage Agastya established his abode here and performed intense penance for the welfare of humanity.
history.legendQuote: According to sacred tradition, during the celestial wedding of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati at Mount Kailasa, the earth tilted northward due to the congregation of all celestial beings. To counterbalance the earth, Sage Agastya was sent southward.
history.legendDesc2: On his journey, he encountered the Vindhya mountain range, which had grown excessively tall and obstructed the paths of the Sun and Moon. The sage commanded the mountains to bow down and remain so until his return. As Sage Agastya never returned, the Vindhyas remain humbled to this day.
history.legendDesc3: By the divine grace of Lord Shiva, Sage Agastya was able to witness the celestial wedding at Kailasa from this very place.
history.riverDesc1: In those times, South India was largely arid and lacked sufficient water sources. Through his intense tapasya, Sage Agastya prayed to Lord Shiva and Goddess Ganga, resulting in the creation of several sacred rivers. One such river is the Swarnamukhi.
history.riverDesc2p1: The Swarnamukhi River originates from the Mallepalli Hills near Adinepalli, about 30 km southwest of Tirupati on the Chittoor route. Flowing through the Hemanaga (Golden) Hills of Chandragiri, it acquired the name
history.triveniDesc: Near the temple, the rivers Bhima and Kalyani merge with the Swarnamukhi, forming the sacred Triveni Sangamam, also known as Mukkoti Sthalam. This confluence is considered highly auspicious for holy baths, pitru tarpanam, abhishekam, and pradakshina.
history.riverDesc3: After the advent of the Swarnamukhi River, this valley transformed into a serene and picturesque landscape, surrounded by the Mallepalli Hills to the south, Chandragiri Hills to the west, and the Seshachalam Hills to the north, with an open valley to the east.
history.lingamDesc: One day, while bathing in the river, Sage Agastya discovered a Shiva Lingam submerged in the deep waters. He consecrated it on the riverbank and installed it as Sri Agastheeswara Swamy. Subsequently, a temple was constructed, and Sri Anandavalli Ammavaru was installed as the consort deity.
history.archDesc: The temple architecture reflects classical Chola style with later Vijayanagara additions. A well-proportioned sanctum (garbhagriha), a three-tier Rajagopuram, spacious mandapams, and a beautifully carved 16-pillared mandapam stand as testimony to its historical and artistic heritage.
history.kshetrasDesc: Along the course of the Swarnamukhi River flourished several ancient Shaiva Kshetras alongside renowned Vaishnava Kshetras such as Tirumala, Tirupati, Tiruchanoor, and Srinivasa Mangapuram.
history.festivalsDesc: Daily rituals are performed as per Shaiva Agama traditions. The following occasions are observed with great devotion:
history.annualFestivalDesc: Celebrated for three days during Kartika Pournami:

location.title: How to Reach
location.subtitle: Plan Your Sacred Visit
location.mapNote: Click on the map to get directions via Google Maps
location.routeDesc: The temple is located on the Tirupati–Chittoor–Bengaluru Highway, approximately 10 km from Tirupati. It is situated about 1 km before Chandragiri Fort, the historic capital of the Vijayanagara Empire.
location.geoDesc: After the advent of the Swarnamukhi River, this valley transformed into a serene and picturesque landscape, surrounded by the Mallepalli Hills to the south, Chandragiri Hills to the west, and the Seshachalam Hills to the north, with an open valley to the east.

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.subtitle: We Welcome Your Inquiries
contact.subject: Subject
contact.responseTime: We will respond to your inquiry within 2-3 business days.

management.title: Temple Management
management.subtitle: Generations of Devoted Stewardship
management.introDesc: In 1909 AD, the temple was renovated by Sri Natukoti Chettiar of Tamil Nadu, who also undertook the renovation of the Sri Kalahasteeswara Temple. Subsequently, the responsibility for the temple's maintenance was entrusted to the Mogili Reddy family, who have preserved its sanctity with deep devotion.
management.trustee1Name: Sri M. Chandramouli Reddy, IAS Garu
management.trustee1Desc: As the Hereditary Trustee, Sri M. Chandramouli Reddy, IAS Garu, along with his brother Sri M. Sundara Rami Reddy Garu, served as Managing Trustees of Sri Mukkoti Agastheeswara Swamy Temple for 41 years. Their leadership has been instrumental in the temple's spiritual and infrastructural development.
management.trustee2Name: Sri M. Sundara Rami Reddy Garu
management.trustee2Desc: Serving alongside the Hereditary Trustee for over four decades, Sri M. Sundara Rami Reddy Garu dedicated his life to the service of Lord Agastheeswara and the devotees who visit this sacred shrine.
management.trustee3Name: Sri M. Raghu Rami Reddy Garu
management.trustee3Desc: Subsequently, their cousin Sri M. Raghurami Reddy Garu served the temple as Managing Trustee for 17 years, continuing the family's legacy of devoted service to this ancient Shaiva Kshetram.
management.legacyDesc: Through their dedicated leadership and selfless service spanning decades, the temple has experienced significant spiritual and infrastructural development. The Mogili Reddy family's stewardship has ensured that this sacred Shaiva Kshetram continues to serve devotees with the same reverence and sanctity it has maintained for centuries.
management.templeAlsoKnown: The temple is also popularly known as Sri Mukkoti Agastheeswara Swamy Temple.

footer.footerDesc: A sacred Shaiva Kshetram on the banks of the Swarnamukhi River, near Tirupati, Andhra Pradesh.

nandi.greeting: Namaskaram! I am Nandi, the eternal guardian of Lord Shiva. How may I guide you today?
